I'm sorry.  I was trying to be funny, and it looks like I failed.
 
To answer your specific question, there have been times in my career
where it hasn't been commercially desirable to improve design.  Usually,
improving design takes some amount of time and effort.  Sometimes, the
costs of that improvement exceed the value of the improved design.  In
those cases, we've made the right business decision to NOT improve the
product's design.
 
To tie this back to JUnit, having a good test suite always decreases the
cost of improving design.
 
 
Todd.
 
 
 


________________________________

	From: Soaring Eagle [mailto:comfortable.numb@...] 
	Sent: Tuesday, February 15, 2005 12:02 PM
	To: junit@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: Re: [junit] Testing certain types of methods
	
	
	Todd,
	
	I dont see the "bad" connotation in the text of my email.
Anyways -
	here is the question repeated.
	
	Do you mean that sometimes it is not commercially desirable to
	improvde design and at such times, JUnit's inability to be
flexible is
	a limitation?
	
	Group,
	
	I guess I understand what this thread means, but if anyone wants
to
	confirm it, that will be good too.
